resources: "A The cost of producing Good X in money terms. ENDSTOPB The foregone output from the next best alternative use to which factors of production used to produce Good X could be put. ENDSTOPC The stream of services provided by Good X over its entire lifetime. ENDSTOPD The production of Good X foregone in the previous year to enable Good X to be produced this year." "A buyers can but are not willing to purchase at different prices ENDSTOPB buyers are both willing and able to purchase at one particular price ENDSTOPC will be supplied at different prices ENDSTOPD buyers are both willing and able to purchase at different prices" "A more one consumes of Good X, the less utility one derives from the first unit of consumption of Good X ENDSTOPB total utility derived from the consumption of Good X increases by smaller amounts for each extra unit of Good X consumed ENDSTOPC marginal utility derived from the consumption of an extra unit of Good X falls if the price of Good X falls ENDSTOPD marginal utility derived from the consumption of an extra unit of Good X falls if the price of Good X rises" "A supply is zero ENDSTOPB supply is infinite ENDSTOPC demand is zero ENDSTOPD demand is 1" "A A fall in consumers incomes. ENDSTOPB A rise in the price of a complementary good. ENDSTOPC A fall in the price of a substitute good. ENDSTOPD A rise in the price of the normal good." "A The demand curve has a positive slope. ENDSTOPB The income effect on demand of a price change will affect demand in the opposite direction to the substitution effect. ENDSTOPC The substitution effect of a fall in price of the good will lead to a fall in demand. ENDSTOPD Demand falls if income increases, other things being equal." "A achieve a greater average revenue than if it charged a single price ENDSTOPB achieve lower total production costs per unit of output ENDSTOPC increase its profits and simultaneously lower its profit maximising output ENDSTOPD increase its profits by reducing its production costs more than its total revenue" "A remain unchanged ENDSTOPB shift to the right but not change slope ENDSTOPC shift to the right and become steeper ENDSTOPD shit to the right and become less steep" "A If more labour is added to a given amount of capital, the marginal product of labour remains unchanged. ENDSTOPB If the ratio of labour to capital doubles, the output of the firm also doubles. ENDSTOPC If both the input of capital and labour doubles, output remains constant. ENDSTOPD If the input of capital and labour doubles, the ratio of output to inputs is unchanged." "A Some degree of monopoly power ensures that in the long run firms can make supernormal profits. ENDSTOPB There is freedom of entry and exit into the industry. ENDSTOPC Firms in the industry produce differentiated products. ENDSTOPD Firms in the industry charge prices above their marginal costs of production." "A will seek to make only satisfactory rather than maximum profits ENDSTOPB has a discontinuity in its marginal revenue curve ENDSTOPC has a discontinuity in its marginal cost curve ENDSTOPD has a discontinuity in its average revenue curve" "A most people risk averse ENDSTOPB most people risk neutral ENDSTOPC most people risk loving ENDSTOPD none of the above" "A average cost curve ENDSTOPB average variable cost curve ENDSTOPC marginal cost curve above the lowest point of the average total cost curve ENDSTOPD marginal cost curve above the lowest point of the average variable cost curve" "A The purchase of a £1,000 United Kingdom government bond. ENDSTOPB A museum purchases an 18th century work of art. ENDSTOPC A firm increases the quantity of cars it holds as stock. ENDSTOPD A firm places £1 million of its surplus funds with a United Kingdom bank in a high interest account." "A £166 million ENDSTOPB £200 million ENDSTOPC £500 million ENDSTOPD £1,000 million" "A rise and real GDP will fall ENDSTOPB stay the same and real GDP will rise ENDSTOPC rise and real GDP will rise ENDSTOPD fall and real GDP will rise" "A The multiplier has a value of 4. ENDSTOPB An increase in the income level will raise the marginal propensity to consume. ENDSTOPC The economy is in equilibrium if output is £200 million. ENDSTOPD None of the above." "A A decrease in government expenditure. ENDSTOPB A decrease in the income tax rate. ENDSTOPC An increase autonomous savings. ENDSTOPD A increase in the rate of interest." "A £150 million ENDSTOPB £200 million ENDSTOPC £450 million ENDSTOPD none of the above" "A 0 per cent ENDSTOPB 10 per cent ENDSTOPC 10 per cent times the velocity of circulation ENDSTOPD 10 per cent divided by the velocity of circulation" "A reduce output and increase employment ENDSTOPB reduce output and employment ENDSTOPC increase output and reduce employment ENDSTOPD increase output and employment" "A inflation and economic growth ENDSTOPB inflation and unemployment ENDSTOPC inflation and balance of payments equilibrium ENDSTOPD inflation and a stable exchange rate" "A higher domestic interest rates and an exchange rate appreciation ENDSTOPB higher domestic interest rates and an exchange rate depreciation ENDSTOPC lower domestic interest rates and an exchange rate appreciation ENDSTOPD lower domestic interest rates and an exchange rate depreciation" "A £50 million in surplus ENDSTOPB £50 million in deficit ENDSTOPC £250 million in deficit ENDSTOPD £350 million in deficit" "A exports will become less competitive ENDSTOPB imports will become more expensive ENDSTOPC inflation will rise ENDSTOPD export volumes will rise" "A Country B has a comparative advantage in the production of both wine and clothENDSTOPB Country A has a comparative advantage in the production of wine and Country B has a comparative advantage in the production of clothENDSTOPC Country A has a comparative advantage in the production of cloth and Country B has a comparative advantage in the production of wine ENDSTOPD neither country has a comparative advantage in the production of either wine or cloth"
